text:
1. Your full name: Johan P. Rempel

2. Your address: Box 5-20

3. Date: Mar 26/62

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Morris, Man.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Johan Rempel, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April, 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Village of Rosemont, close to Morris, Man., from birth to time when moving to Sask.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.): Born in Western Canada

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: Better chances in Sask. Could take up homestead. Liked to see what the prairie were like.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through other people, neighbors, relatives. Also through advertising by an agent.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Strongly thought was a good move, good to spread out a bit.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   In a group of 5 brothers.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Journey took six days. Water took away down at Moosejaw. Couldn't continue till dam had been restored back Sand Lake. This was still the old track - the new one was started summer of 1904. Met Indians.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Herbert, in a tent. Herbert was about 2 or 3 shanties.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   13 miles North west of Herbert.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Have always lived around Herbert. Took up another farm later on, 9 miles from town.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Always farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Although it was a good move, good to spread out a bit.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    In a group of 3 brothers.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Train.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    Journey took six days. Water took away, came at Moose Jaw. Couldn't continue till came had been restored back. Sand bags. This was still the old track - the new one was started summer of 1907. Most Indians.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    Herbert, in a tent. Herbert was about 2 or 3 shanties.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
    13 miles North west of Herbert.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    Have always lived around Herbert. Took up another farm later on, 9 miles from town.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
    Always farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Old home not so far away. Wrote perhaps monthly.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Married to Sarah Wall, at Herbert, wedding in Uncle's house, 1906.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Yes, I believe some came because of our recommendation.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.
   Jacob - fall of 1904
   Parents -
   Other family members - fall of 1904

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   In summer of 1804 took a trip with some prospective settlers to see the land. Took a wagon, tent, some camping equipment. Stopped from Mo. to Sask. without seeing a single person. Came to S Current, a few small buildings, somebody called it Ranch Town.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Yes, was a sort of helping agent for prospective settlers. However, wagon was means of transportation. Church wasn't too far away - often walked to church.
25. When was the first car used in the community? about 1912 (Rio).

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make? bought my car 1934.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Herbert, 13 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) Generally, Herbert, later some buying in S. Current.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once a month sometimes.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1922.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period. About 1912 - Groceries, Clothes, at first height our mail orders came to about 1/3 of all purchases, later with better stores this became less.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1913, Main Centre Farmers Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? We didn't intend to stay. We were going to improve the homestead & sell out. However later stayed, married local girl and made this our home.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
Yes, from about 1907. Some moved back. Too lonely, too hard, difficult.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
Yes! A good percentage returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
Assessor and agent - 1904-1909 in summer.
Road Foreman - 1912-1935.
School Trustee - 1912-1940 approx.
Meter Telephone Co - 1914 - Several years.
Memorial Insurance agent - 1915-1940 approx.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
None

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
Main Centre - received its name from the school, which was named that way by myself & other trustees because it was in centre between James & Herbert.
Stark School - Fusion School - received their names from the large group of Stark & Fusion respectively.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)

Receipt of Homestead 1903 - my own.
Some pictures from 1904

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? [ ]
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? [ ]
(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

John - lives at Herbert, farming.
George - McNeely, man - labourer.
Jack - man, man - labourer.
Fred - S. Current, Saeb - Matt's Star Service.
(over to back)

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

1. Transportation - #1 highway.
2. Farming system - Power farming.
3. S. Current growth.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

1. Mr. Nathan Jackson, Herbert, Saeb.
2. Mr. Bert Butterworth, Herbert, Saeb.
3. Mr. George P. Ryde, Herbert, Box 529, Saeb.

Dick Evans
